statement:
Let $k$ be a positive integer and let $\delta>0$. There exists a
positive integer $N=N(k,\delta)$ such that every subset of
$\{1,2,\dotsc,N\}$ of $\delta N$ contains an arithmetic progression of
length $k$.

The case $k=3$ was first proved by Roth[@cite:roth_szem_three]. His
method did not seem to extend to the case $k>3$. Using completely
different ideas Szemerédi proved the case $k=4$
[@cite:szemeredi_szemth_four], and the general case of an arbitrary $k$
[@cite:szemeredi_szemth_gen].

The best known bounds for $N(k,\delta)$ are
$$e^{c (\log \frac{1}{\delta})^{k-1}}\leq N(k,\delta)\leq 2^{2^{\delta^{-2^{2^{k+9}}}}},$$
where the lower bound is due to Behrend[@cite:behrend_szem_low] (for
$k=3$) and Rankin[@cite:rankin_behrgen], and the upper bound is due to
Gowers[@cite:gowers_szem_new_gen].

For $k=3$ a better upper bound was obtained by Bourgain
$$N(3,\delta)\leq c \delta^{-2} e^{2^{56} \delta^{-2}}.$$
